newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentina's YPF sees no bias in Falkland oil bids.
newsitem.headline: Argentina's YPF sees no bias in Falkland oil bids.

text.p: Argentine oil giant YPF SA ruled out discrimination in its failure to win a license for oil exploration in the disputed Falkland Islands, in bid results announced on Monday.
YPF President Nells Leon was quoted by state news agency Telam saying the tender outcome, in which a joint bid from YPF and British Gas was the only one to fail, was "simply a market matter."
"In no way does it constitute an act of discrimination against Argentina," said Nells Leon.

The Argentine government, which maintains a stake in YPF, also said it was confident there was no hidden agenda and it accepted the Falkland government's explanation that British Gas and YPF failed "partly because they limited their bidding to the two most successful tranches."

The bids awarded on Monday are for the North Falkland Basin, seven tranches covering about 12,800 square km. The Falklands government said the next round would "almost certainly" cover the so-called "Special Cooperation Area" straddling the median line between the islands and the Argentine mainland.
Leon promised that YPF would make bids "in tenders for other areas of the Malvinas" -- the Argentine name for the British-run islands over, which Britain and Argentina fought a 10-week war in 1982.

Argentina still claims sovereignty, but the two nations resumed diplomatic ties in 1989 and came to an agreement about oil exploration a year ago. This year they set up a joint committee to administer exploration in Falkland Island waters.
